vertices.name: Dense subset of a metric space
vertices.content:
Let $(M,d)$ be a metric space. A subset $N$ of $M$ is said to be dense if every ball $B(x,r)\subset M$, we have
      $$B(x,r)\cap N \neq \varnothing.$$.

vertices.name: $\sigma$-algebra
vertices.content:
A collection of subsets of $\Omega$ such that
1) $\Omega\in\F$
2) $A\in\F$ implies $A^c\in\F$
3) $\{A_n\}_{n\in\NN}\subset\F$ implies $\cup_{n=1}^{\infty}A_n\in\F$
The doublet $(\Omega,\F)$ is called a measurable space.

vertices.name: Generated $\sigma$-algebra
vertices.content:
Let $\C$ be a collection of subsets of $\Omega$. Then 
      $$\sigma(\C) = \bigcap \{ \F : \F \text{ is a $\sigma$-algebra and } \C\subset\F \}$$
      is the smallest $\sigma$-algebra containing $\C$, called the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\C$

vertices.name: Measurable space
vertices.content: Let $\F$ be a $\sigma$-algebra on $\Omega$. The doublet $(\Omega,\F)$ is called a measurable space.

vertices.name: Almost everywhere
vertices.content:
Let $(\Omega, \F, \mu)$ be a measure space. A property $\P:\Omega\to\{\mathrm{true},\mathrm{false}\}$ is said to hold almost everywhere with respect to $\mu$, abbreviated by $\mu$-a.e. if
                $$\mu\left(\left\{x\in\Omega : \neg \P(x)\right\}\right) = 0.$$

vertices.name: Measure
vertices.content:
Let $(\Omega,\F)$ be a measurable space. A measure is a function $\mu:\F\to[0,\infty]$ such that
                  </br>
                  1) $\mu(\varnothing) = 0$
                  </br>
                  2) ($\sigma$-additivity) For every family $\{A_i\}_{i\in\N}$ of disjoint measurable subsets, we have
                  $$\mu\left(\bigcup\limits_{i=1}^\infty A_i\right) = \sum\limits_{i=1}^\infty \mu(A_i).$$

vertices.name: Probability measure
vertices.content: A measure $\PP$ on $(\Omega, \F)$ is a probability measure if $\PP(\Omega)$ = 1.

vertices.name: Measure space
vertices.content: Let $\mu$ be a measure on a measurable space $(\Omega,\F)$. The triplet $(\Omega,\F, \mu)$ is called a measure space

vertices.name: Measure kernel
vertices.content:
Let $(\Omega, \F)$ and $(\Gamma, \G)$ be measurable spaces. A function $\kappa: (\Omega,\G) \to [0,\infty]$ is a measure kernel if
      </br>
      1) For each $B\in\G$, $\omega \mapsto \kappa(\omega,B)$ is $(\F\to\B([0,\infty]))$-measurable
      </br>
      2) For each $\omega\in\Omega$, $B \mapsto \kappa(\omega,B)$ is a measure on $\G$. For a measurable function $f: \Gamma\to\RR$, we write the integral of $f$ with respect to $\kappa(\omega,B)$ as $\int f(y)\d\kappa(\omega,y) := \int f(y)\kappa(\omega,\d y)$
      </br>
      If $(\Omega, \F) = (\Gamma, \G)$, we call $\kappa$ a measure kernel on $(\Omega, \F)$.

vertices.name: Product of kernels
vertices.content:
Let $\kappa, \lambda$ be measure kernels on $(\Omega, \F)$. The product of $\kappa$ and $\lambda$ is a measure kernel on $(\Omega, \F)$, defined by
      $$(\kappa\lambda)(x,B) = \int\kappa(x,\dy)\lambda(y, B).$$

vertices.name: Probability space
vertices.content: A measure space $(\Omega, \F, \PP)$ is a probability space if $\PP$ is a probability measure. In such case, each element of $\Omega$ is called an outcome and each element of $\F$ is called an event.

vertices.name: Random variable
vertices.content: Let $(\Omega, \F, \PP)$ be a probability space. A function $X : \Omega\to\RR^d$ is called a random variable if $X$ is $(\F\to\B(\RR^d))$-measurable. We will write $\B_X := \B(\RR^d))$, the Borel $\sigma$-algebra associated to $X$.

vertices.name: Distribution
vertices.content:
Let $(\Omega, \F, \PP)$ be a probability space and $X$ be a $d$-dimensional random variable. Then $X$ induces a measure $\PP_X(B) : \B(\RR^d) \to \R$ such that 
      $$\PP_X(B) = \PP(X^{-1}(B)),$$ called the distribution or the law of $X$.
